images.copyright: Kinder Scout at sunrise, Peak District National Park, England (© john finney photography/Getty Images)
images.title: A park for the people
images.caption: Kinder Scout, Peak District National Park, UK
images.desc: Within the vast expanse of the Peak District National Park in the United Kingdom lies the Kinder Scout Nature Reserve, the site of a significant people's movement in British history. At around 635 metres, Kinder Scout stands tall as the highest point in the Peak District, its rugged moorlands and windswept plateaus having drawn adventurers and nature enthusiasts for generations. In 1932, this area was the stage for a historic mass trespass, where hundreds of people on foot protested for public access to these lands. This act of civil disobedience contributed to the passing of legislation that established national parks in the United Kingdom. The creation of the Peak District National Park ensured that these hills and valleys would be preserved for future generations to enjoy, marking a significant victory for public access and conservation efforts.

og.title: Kinder Scout, Peak District National Park, UK
og.desc: Within the vast expanse of the Peak District National Park in the United Kingdom lies the Kinder Scout Nature Reserve, the site of a…

images.copyright: Aerial view of colourful houses on a headland in Puerto de la Cruz, Tenerife, Spain (© Marco Bottigelli/Getty Images)
images.title: Vibrant colours all year round!
images.caption: Puerto de la Cruz, Tenerife, Spain
images.desc: Sun-kissed beaches, colourful buildings, clear waters and rich history—there's something special going on in the city of Puerto de la Cruz. Located on Tenerife, the largest of Spain's Canary Islands, it stared out as a fishing village. The city's centre is full of charming streets and historical buildings. For those seeking sun, sea and sand, Playa Jardín is the city's answer. This black volcanic sand beach, designed by the renowned architect César Manrique, offers lush gardens, unique sculptures and views of the world's third tallest volcano, Mount Teide. Other landmarks here include Lago Martiánez, a complex of seawater pools offering a scenic retreat, and Loro Parque, a world-famous zoo and conservation centre. So, take a moment, savour the image and let your imagination set sail to this lively port town!

og.title: Puerto de la Cruz, Tenerife, Spain
og.desc: Sun-kissed beaches, colourful buildings, clear waters and rich history—there's something special going on in the city of Puerto de la Cruz…

images.copyright: Sperm whale pod surfacing, Dominica (© Franco Banfi/Minden Pictures)
images.title: Taking a breather
images.caption: Sperm whale pod surfacing
images.desc: Ahoy there, giants of the sea! The planet's 92 whale species are split between baleen whales and toothed whales. Baleen whales use bristle-like mouth parts to filter krill from the water. The sperm whales pictured here, like the other 76 toothed species, use cone-shaped teeth to attack their prey. Unlike baleen whales, they hunt and navigate using echolocation, a method that uses sound to detect the things around them. Sperm whales also happen to have the largest brain of any animal on Earth! A whale's large brain-to-body mass ratio means that their intelligence is no fluke.

og.title: Sperm whale pod surfacing
og.desc: Ahoy there, giants of the sea! The planet's 92 whale species are split between baleen whales and toothed whales. Baleen whales use bristle…

images.copyright: Kailasa temple in Ellora caves complex in India (© mazzzur/Getty Images)
images.title: A megalithic wonder
images.caption: Kailasa temple in Ellora caves
images.desc: Kailasa temple in Ellora Caves near the Aurangabad district of Maharashtra, is celebrated for its colossal size, intricate stone architecture and artistic finesse evident in its sculpture. This temple stretches along a basalt cliff for over two kilometres and is intricately carved. Towering above the surrounding landscape, the sanctuary's peak reaches an impressive height of 32 metres above the court below. A legend weaves through the stones of Ellora, recounting the tale of a king from Alajapura. After being miraculously cured from a terrible illness by a sacred bath, the king and his queen pledged to construct a temple in honour of Lord Shiva.

og.title: Kailasa temple in Ellora caves

images.copyright: Female pyrrhuloxia perched on cactus plant, Texas (© outtakes/Getty Images)
images.title: Dapper in the desert
images.caption: Female pyrrhuloxia in Texas, USA
images.desc: In today's image is a pyrrhuloxia—also known as the desert cardinal—a songbird that lives in the deserts of northern Mexico and the American Southwest. The female cardinal, while lacking the flamboyant colouration of her male counterpart, possesses a unique charm in her own right. While she shares the distinctive crest and red bill with the male, her plumage is a more subdued yellowish, cinnamon-brown, adorned only with subtle touches of red. Unlike females in many bird species, the female cardinal is an accomplished vocalist, harmonising with the melodies of the male.

og.title: Female pyrrhuloxia in Texas, USA

images.copyright: Hippopotamus mother and calf, South Luangwa National Park, Zambia (© Nature Picture Library/Alamy)
images.title: Admire from afar!
images.caption: South Luangwa National Park, Zambia
images.desc: All eyes are on hippopotamuses today! This peeping calf in today's image is still under the watchful eye of its mother and will continue to be so until nursing ends at about eight months. The third-largest land mammals—after elephants and white rhinos—deserve our attention. The chubby mammals, with an impressive weight of up to 1,500 kilograms, might seem cute, but their strong jaws, large teeth and aggressive behaviour make them one of the world's most dangerous wild animals. Categorised as a vulnerable species by the International Union for Conservation of Nature, these semiaquatic animals are native to Sub-Saharan Africa. So, admire them from a safe distance—despite their short legs, they are also fast runners!

images.copyright: Vasant Panchmi celebration in Noida, India (© Burhaan Kinu/Hindustan Times via Getty Images)
images.title: Offerings for the spring
images.caption: Vasant Panchmi
images.copyrightonly: © Burhaan Kinu/Hindustan Times via Getty Images
images.desc: Vasant Panchami, also known as Saraswati Puja, is an auspicious Hindu festival that marks the onset of spring in India. The associated festivities vary across regions within religions, with each community adding its own unique flavour to the celebration. The observance of the Vasant Utsava on Panchami itself is strategically timed, aligning with the belief that any season's transition period spans 40 days. For countless individuals, this occasion is a devoted celebration of the goddess Saraswati, revered as the embodiment of knowledge, language, music and different art representations. Goddess Saraswati stands as a symbol of creative energy and power in its myriad forms, encapsulating both the essence of longing and love. The exuberant celebration extends to culinary customs, where some infuse saffron into rice, creating a golden feast as part of the elaborate rituals.

og.title: Vasant Panchmi

images.copyright: Mardi Gras beads in the Marigny, New Orleans (© Erik Pronske Photography/Getty Images)
images.title: Strands of celebration
images.caption: Marigny, New Orleans, USA
images.desc: Let the good times roll! Also called Fat Tuesday or Shrove Tuesday, Mardi Gras is celebrated to live life to the fullest before fasting and giving up other indulgences for Lent—though many modern celebrators are just happy to use the occasion as an excuse to party. During the festive revelry of Mardi Gras in New Orleans, the tradition of 'throws' adds an extra layer of excitement to the celebrations. Throws are strings of beads, doubloons, cups and an assortment of trinkets, distributed or hurled from colourful floats to the exuberant spectators lining the streets. These throws are a cherished part of the Mardi Gras experience. Ready to make merry and join the parade?
